title: Palm OS
overview: Palm OS debuts on personal digital assistants (PDAs), becoming one of the first successful handheld operating systems with touch and stylus input.

title: BlackBerry OS
overview: BlackBerry OS launches with a focus on secure mobile email and enterprise messaging, dominating corporate mobile communication in the 2000s.

title: Symbian OS
overview: Symbian becomes the leading smartphone OS, powering devices from Nokia, Ericsson, and others before the rise of iOS and Android.

title: Apple iOS
overview: Apple introduces iOS with the first iPhone, bringing a multitouch interface and App Store ecosystem that transform the smartphone industry.

title: Android OS
overview: Google launches Android 1.0 on the HTC Dream, quickly becoming the worldâ€™s most widely used smartphone operating system.

title: Windows Phone
overview: Microsoft introduces Windows Phone with a tile-based interface, attempting to compete with iOS and Android in the smartphone market.

title: Samsung Bada OS
overview: Samsung launches Bada OS for mid-range smartphones, though it is later merged into the Tizen project.

title: Tizen OS
overview: Samsung and Intel develop Tizen as a Linux-based OS for smartphones, wearables, and IoT devices, though adoption remains niche.

title: Firefox OS
overview: Mozilla introduces Firefox OS, an HTML5-based mobile operating system targeting low-cost smartphones, but it is discontinued in 2016.

title: Windows 10 Mobile
overview: Microsoft rebrands Windows Phone as Windows 10 Mobile, but market adoption dwindles, leading to its discontinuation in 2019.

title: Huawei HarmonyOS
overview: Huawei launches HarmonyOS (HongmengOS in China) as an alternative ecosystem for smartphones, IoT, and wearables in response to trade restrictions.
